THE PRACTICE OF MEDICINE IN THE TROPICS.
Dear General Carter,
div1.p:
Your letter of February 12th reached me
yesterday; many thanks for the information it contains.
Before you receive this, you will have had a cable from me
saying that an additional two thousand words can be placed at
your disposal should you still require them, and I hope it will
not be too late for you to make use of them. As you say 20%
more words would make the article 100% more valuable I feel
that we must make room for such an expansion.

I hope Noguchi is going to allow you to
quote his recent work. As you know he is one of our contribu-
tors and anything that will improve the book will be indirectly
to his own advantage. In any case the book will not be coming
out for many months and would therefore of necessity follow any
papers he may be publishing on the subject. I had seen a brief
reference to his discovery which, I understand, is the finding
of a minute spirochaete in the peripheral blood. I shall be
interested to read your account of what he has done.

As you are pressed for time please submit
your article in any order in which you may have written it and
I would undertake to group the information according to our
general scheme, and let you see the proofs before publication.
This will allow you also, to add additional information at a
later date.
